Topic.Title: So what happens to my shares if it goes private?

Message.Msg: Founder and CEO Michael Dell—along with Silver Lake Partners—will offer Dell's holders a per-share price of $13.65 in cash. The stock closed Tuesday at $13.42 on Nasdaq. ============== This means that DELL trading symbol is no longer exists and you will be given $13.65 cash for every share you own.

Message.Title: This deal is by far done.
Message.Msg: A protection put in place by the board REQUIRES a so called majority of the minority vote. There are 2 votes that will take place and BOTH must pass with a majority for the deal to go. 1) M. Dell must approve. 2) Majority of shareholders EXCLUDING M. Dell must approve. Both must pass for the deal to go. This is big and does shed new light on the rest of us shareholders. We already have one fund with 14.4 million shares voting NO. It would be interesting in the next few days to see where the big funds stand.

Topic.Title: This deal is by far done.

Message.Msg: If you look at the major holders, they control close to 30% of the stock. That 30% is more significant when you remove M. Dell's 14% position out of the vote! So even if half of them start raising a stink and the public gets wind the buyout might be in trouble. I think there will be a higher offer. If you read the protections put in by the board, it really does show the board did have the shareholders best interests in mind. I'm no expert but I think the offer will be closer to $15. Just think about it, SOUTHEASTERN ASSET MANAGEMENT has 7.5% of the stock. And for the minority vote, that stake is even higher. What do they have to lose by publicly saying they won't vote yes? It would be wrong not to try to get a higher price. Even if they get $1 more that is $130M more for their fund holders. They have nothing to lose. They even publicly said they feel it's worth around $20. It's been rumored Silver Lake would pay up to $15, so it would be foolish for any of these major holder not to push for $15. Disclaimer: I did buy some $14 calls. I'm speculating! I know I could lose my $$ on this. :)

Topic.Title: stockholder vote

Message.Msg: No chance of a stockholder vote begating this deal. First of all, we are currently in a waiting period termed "go shop" where other company's and, or, groups are welcome to make a purchase offer for the company. When no other offers materialize it is impossible to make the case that the current $13.65 offer is inadequate, as so many amateurs here seem to think. Second, voter participation in these type situations is typically about 5%. In other words, nearly all common stockholders choose not to make the effort to cast a vote. Smart money bought in here last year at prices from $9 to $10, where the stock traded for quite awhile. Those owners began taking their profits a couple of weeks ago, when rumors of the buyout pushed the stock up 20%. And the balance of people recognized their profit yesterday, once the deal was officially announced. The buy trades now are arbitrageurs buying in volume and looking to capitalize on the current ..20 to .25 cents on the difference from the current market trading price ($13.40) and the final deal price ($13.65). Hope this helps.

Topic.Title: why isnt it at 13.65-its gauranteed-

Message.Msg: (1) It isn't gauranteed (sic) - the deal could still fall through or not be approved by shareholders (2) if the deal does go through shareholders won't be paid until July so there is a time value to keeping your money locked up, e.g. you could sell now and park your money elsewhere to earn interest risk-free If you think its worth paying 13.44 now to (hopefully) get 13.65 in the future by all means, by more shares - that's how the market works. The chance of another buyer coming in between now and then is also priced into the mix.

Message.Title: Doesn't add up..
Message.Msg: So deal is valued at 24.4B. So it appears they are just buying the float of 1.47B shares at a total of $20.5B. So the remaining 285M shares are owned by the company and are financing the rest of this deal? What am I missing? So if another bidder wanted this they could most likely find the same financing from the bank but put up more cash (3.4B (M Dells stock) +.7B (M Dells cash) + 2B MSFT + 1.4B Silverlake = $7.5) say increase it by $500M ($8B cash required) puts it at $13.91 or adding $1B ($8.5B) put this at $14.18. So with cashflow of $3B within 3 years you have your initial investment back.

Message.Title: Breach of fiduciary duty. Clearly
Message.Msg: DOVER, Del. (AP) -- A lawsuit challenging plans to take troubled personal computer maker Dell Inc. private is being filed in Delaware. The lawsuit filed Wednesday claims that company founder Michael Dell and a group led by investment firm Silver Lake are trying to buy the Round Rock, Texas-based computer maker on the cheap for $24.4 billion, or $13.65 per share. The lawsuit was filed one day after the management-led leveraged buyout was announced. It accuses Michael Dell and company directors of breaching their fiduciary duties by failing to maximize shareholder value and selling the company at an inadequate price at the expense of minority shareholders. Anticipating resistance to the deal from stockholders, Dell's board has said other potential buyers will have 45 days for to submit higher bids.

Topic.Title: today was good

Message.Msg: As I have posted here several times, lawsuits materialize with every single merger and acquisition, whether the deal was a takeunder, a 105 premium, 50% premium, or even 100% premium price. Law firms file suit so that they may join together and collect settlement fees paid by insurance companies. In the case of DELL I expect a dozen different lawsuits and law firms will be involved. In the end they will divy up about $2 million in fees, paid for by the insurance companies representing.. The law suits have nothing to do with changing the announced deal price of $13.65, negotiating money for common stockholders, or anything like that. Hope this helps.

Topic.Title: Shareholders Can Easily Get a Higher Price

Message.Msg: Companies are run to benefit a few. Take the offer, or the company could flounder and go away and you could get nothing in a few years. Any ideas to turn the company arround could get passed on to another company

Message.Title: 750 MIL for a 24 BILLION $$$ Company ?? Mike made out like a bandit !!!!!
Message.Msg: What a deal. I will give you three dollars for every 100 dollars of your business is worth.

Topic.Title: Breach of fiduciary duty. Clearly

Message.Msg: I agree. It is terrible. That is why Dell will face many lawsuits. The lawsuits will try to stop it.

Topic.Title: Handling loss in IRA account

Message.Msg: Tricky rules, but it can be done. Like I said, the easier of the 2 is Roth, and Im not saying its the best thing to do, I was just answering the original posters question, and that answer is yes, there are ways. Close out all of your Roth IRA accounts and the total amount you receive has to be less than your basis in the account. The basis = the total amount youve contributed plus any money converted into a Roth minus any earlier withdrawals and blah blah blah. There are similar steps for traditional. Im no expert in this area at all, but there are ways for both. But quite frankly, its all mumbo jumbo to me.
